Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2015 02:26AM GwennyMD wrote: Chloesmom My toes also hurt when I had to wear closed shoes. Whey they first started growing I had the same problem as you. The top part did not feel attached and fungus grew in. I considered having them removed but doc said to let RX work. I kept them cut short and continued to use the RX. This past summer they looked a little better so I let the manicurist start using the sanding tool. I can finally wear most of my shoes without any discomfort. Sorry I do not have better news.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2015 12:05AM GwennyMD wrote: I do not post much anymore but should add my experience to your nail discussion. I also had trouble with toenails. I lost a little one and both of the big ones started to detach. All of this happened PFC. I finally went to dermatologist. She cut them down as far as possible and gave me expensive RX. Fortunately it was summertime so I could wear sandals. My big toe nails had always been thick and I did not realize that something was wrong. It took about a year to completely correct. I get pedicures about once a month from person I trust. I started taking Biotin during chemo. My fingernails are better than they were before chemo and my hair is very thick. I am 2 years PFC and I have most of the original length back. I do not know if it has the same texture because I used to keep it straight with either heat or chemicals. Now I wear it natural. I no longer use dryers, curling irons, flat irons, hot combs or relaxers. I cannot be sure if the Biotin has contributed to the successful growth of my hair and nails, but I do not plan to stop taking it until I can pull my hair back into my normal summer poneytail. I had color resistant grey hair before chemo and now it is worse. I continue to use permanent hair color because the others do not work.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2014 03:01AM GwennyMD wrote: Your pictures look great.  I decided to get rid of my gray mop by experimenting with henna.  I wanted my hair to be my normal color - black.  According to the instructions, I had to use red first and then use black.  After I finished it was dark brown with brass and rust colored tips and streaks.  It is now lighter.  I will try to get DD to post pics for me.  I am still wearing wigs.  I had long thick black hair before chemo. I plan to contiue experimenting with color  I will probably stop wearing wigs in May.  By then I should know what color and style I want to wear.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: May 16, 2014 02:43AM GwennyMD wrote: Hi ladies I have not be here for several weeks but I think I may have found another experiment people can try.  My last chemo was 8/15/13. I was on taxatere so the fuzz had been growing for a few weeks. It continued to grow slowly and fill in. By 10/15/13 my hair was like Carrol2 at 13 weeks but mine was all white.  Eventually silver and a few random dark hairs joined in.  By 2/15/14 (6 mos PFC) it looked like Carrol2 at 23 weeks (still white and gray).  Friends and family had been recommending all kinds of oils and treatments.  One person recommended a shampoo with protein.  I had been taking biotin since Sept.  I had another surgery in on 2/15 and started adding protein powder to my smoothies to improve healing.  I began making more green drinks and smoothies and continued adding the protein powder..I usually have it 2 or 3 times a week.  Now, after 3 months my is significantly thicker and  and most of it has grown 2 inches. Since I hated the white hair I began experimenting with henna since it is non toxic.  Unfortunately it does not work very well on stubborn white hair.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2013 02:40AM GwennyMD wrote: I started losing hair after the 14th day of taking AC.  I was never completely bald but had spots of peach fuzz.  When I started taxotere, the hair started growing, slowly at first but then it started filling in nicely.  Unfortunately all of it is silver with a few darks roots.  After 4 months of growth most of it is still under 2 inches.  It is starting to get curly.  I can't wait til it is longer and I can return it to its former color - JET BLACK.   MinusTwo - a friend who took the same or similar cocktail as you, had the same experience with her hair starting to grow at the end of each treatment.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2014 12:46AM GwennyMD wrote: Jojo and Timbekl2 - you both look great.  I am 6 months pfc. I plan to celebrate by changing the color of my 2.5 inch uncontrollable grey mop
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: May 21, 2014 02:51AM GwennyMD wrote: The hair on my face grew like crazy for the first few months PFC.  I did not notice at first because I have always been a "hairy creature" according to my sisters and have been wearing a long wig.  I have shaved the sideburns about 3 times.  It now seems to stay at its previous fuzzy state.  My eyelashes have grown back but they are not as long as they were before.   I am still indecisive about the hair on my head.  I have been wearing a wig since last April.  I do not want to go thru another summer with this thing.  The easiest, cheapest, and least time consuming would be to wear it natural.  It will look like a little curly afro.  I have not worn an afro since 1973 and it was very large.  The next alternative is to have it professionally cut and styled.  This would require a lot of upkeep.  Since I had long hair I always wore ponytail or buns all summer.  Since I refuse to go gray at this young age, the cost of time required to keep it looking good would drive me crazy.  The last alternative would be a wavy hair weave.  My hair would be hidden except for the front edges.  There would be less upkeep but the cost is outrageous.  I hope that by the time I find a shade of brown that I like, I will make my decision. IamNancy - I usually find chin hairs when I am at work.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2014 12:00AM GwennyMD wrote: Oceanbreeze - I started losing my hair after my first treatment of AC.  I cut it short but never shaved.  I lost almost all of it but there were still a few stragly hairs around the edges.  When I started taxotere, the peach fuzz started growing.  It never stopped.  Three weeks after my last taxotere treatment, I had a thin cover of white hair that was at least 1/2 inch long.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2014 01:59PM GwennyMD wrote: When I was first diagnosed it was a week before Xmas in 2012.  For me, the holidays is about indulging, especially when it comes to fatty foods and desserts. My holiday season starts at Thanksgiving and lasts til the end of January.  The month of January includes a couple of birthdays and other celebrations I typically participate in.  Last year, that included the inaguration.  I live in the Washington DC area so my sisters and I attended several parties.  My lumpectomy was scheduled for Feb 7 so I wanted to have a blast before starting treatment. After the lumpectomy we discovered that I needed chemo because the bc had spread to a couple of nodes.  Bummer.  At that time I started doing research about causes, treatments and prevention.  BC runs in my family.  My mom, 2 of her sisters and one of my sisters had BC.  None of them drank or smoke.  In fact, I don't think that mom or her sisters ever indulged. My sister probably indugled during the 1970's but that was 30 years ago.  I smoked for 35 years and stopped 2 years ago.  I am primarily a social drinker who enjoys wine and "girlie drinks".  I don't think that a change in lifestyle could have prevented my getting bc because of my family history.   When I started chemo I tried to change diet by increasing veggies and decreasing processed foods.  I did eliminate alcohol durng the 6 months that I was taking chemo.  I did not want my liver to have to work too hard while cleaning chemo out of my system.  I felt that it was a small sacrifice.  However, my diet went to hell because the chemo screwed up my appetite and taste buds.  I had BMX and DIEP in October.  I could not eat large meals but I focused on lean protein and veggies in order to recover.  When I recovered it was the holdiday season again. I have learned I cannot just stop anything at one time.  I want to eat beter and exercise more to be healthy overall.  We cannot just focus on BC.  I will however still have a slice of birthday cake or an occasional burger.
Posts.Title: Anyone make lifestyle changes? Footballnut vbishop
